text: There are many controversial moments and holes in the plot that contradict the original story 1994, but I still enjoyed finally seeing young Scar and Mufasa, their story of friendship and conflict, the difference in characters. The views of nature as they walk to the promised land are also beautiful. And I must admit that in this film, unlike the previous one, the facial expressions of the characters became more lively and natural, despite the hyperrealism.

author: @Fed-Up-YouTuber
text: The "realistic" CGI art style looks terrible and uncanny. Subjects aren't lit correctly, shadows aren't believable, the color grading is shallow and lacks any contrast, the fur rendering looks inconsistent and blurry, and when the fur is supposed to be wet, it looks completely dry. Should've went with a surreal 3D or 2D style, would have looked better and been cheaper too.

author: @spectre9340
text:
Lore-wise, it still doesn't make sense why Scar isn't the adopted one.

His name "Taka" literally means trash
Whereas "Mufasa" means king??

It also makes sense that Scar would grow up to be resentful and envious of Mufasa. The lion parallel to the Thor-Loki brother dynamic was right there.

Who wrote this taka ?

Edit: another nitpick is that Simba doesn't meet Rafiki until he's an adult

author: @ivanka-vdR
text: Why are people suddenly weirded out by Scar having a British accent? Takes it back to the roots of 1994, the actor back then was British too. I also think this definitely looks way more like the animated version with facial expressions and crazy scenes than the Lion King remake, like they decided to go somewhere in between. Looking kinda realistic but with the charm of the animated LK movies. I don't know if it's any good though, haven't seen the movie but definitely will give it a shot. At least it's a new story, a prequel, instead of just another remake as they could have gone with LK Simba's Pride. But I'm still convinced they should have casted all African voice actors. They should have already considered that in 1994.

author: @khuloodalshamsi6174
text:
I'm really disappointed with how Mufasa's character has been portrayed, especially since I've loved him since I was a kid in the nineties. I wonder if anyone else noticed the big mistake the author made with Scar's character. It seems that Scar was actually very kind as a child and loved Mufasa deeply. Even as they grew up, that love was still there. Yes, in a moment of anger, Scar felt hatred and wanted revenge out of jealousy, but he regretted it at the last moment and tried to protect Mufasa. This shows he had a good heart and didn't want to lose his brother.

Who among us is perfect? We all feel jealousy and anger sometimes, but the best of us are those who repent. Scar regretted his actions and wanted to save Mufasa! After that, Mufasa seemed to hate him so much that he couldn't even say Scar's name and made him feel like an outcast for life. Author, do you realize what you've done? You've made Mufasa appear cruel and spiteful when he was once seen as kind and caring. I really feel let down by this change.

author: @khuloodalshamsi6174
text:
I'm really disappointed with how Mufasa's character has been portrayed, especially since I've loved him since I was a kid in the nineties. I wonder if anyone else noticed the big mistake the author made with Scar's character. It seems that Scar was actually very kind as a child and loved Mufasa deeply. Even as they grew up, that love was still there. Yes, in a moment of anger, Scar felt hatred and wanted revenge out of jealousy, but he regretted it at the last moment and tried to protect Mufasa. This shows he had a good heart and didn't want to lose his brother.

Who among us is perfect? We all feel jealousy and anger sometimes, but the best of us are those who repent. Scar regretted his actions and wanted to save Mufasa! After that, Mufasa seemed to hate him so much that he couldn't even say Scar's name and made him feel like an outcast for life. Author, do you realize what you've done? You've made Mufasa appear cruel and spiteful when he was once seen as kind and caring. I really feel let down by this change.

author: @luckylovella
text: Mufasa was born into a loving family that taught him well. He possessed a remarkable blend of wisdom, courage, intelligence, and love. Taka, on the other hand, inherited his jealous nature from his own father, a lazy individual who failed to instill proper values in him. Despite this, Taka retained a spark of goodness, a legacy from his mother. Fate, however, intertwined their lives. Taka was destined to play a crucial role in saving Mufasa, who was born to be king. Mufasa, in turn, united all the animals of his homeland and ascended to the throne.

author: @LGS27
text:
I continue to see posts and videos claiming that Mufasa â€˜stoleâ€™ everything from Taka/ Scar and that Mufasa is the â€˜trueâ€™ villain so I feel the need to clarify to people what the actual meaning of the story is and how it resembles the fact that no one is really a villain. Although i sympathise for Taka, love his story and understand his perspective itâ€™s crucial to empathise that Mufasa never â€˜tookâ€™ anything from him. It is also crucial to understand the circumstances that coerced Taka into becoming the character we know more closely as Scar.

First, the movie makes it clear that Taka held Mufasaâ€™s life in his hands - and we all know that he ultimately ended it too. That was Takaâ€™s destiny, his fate. But Mufasa did not take his mother, father (1), Sarabi (2) or the throne (3) from Taka nor did he betray Taka as suggested by Obasi, Takaâ€™s father.

1. Takaâ€™s parents differ significantly between the movie and the book. His mother, Eshe, is portrayed as kind, while his father, Obasi, is somewhat naive. Eshe saw something unique in Mufasa, potentially his greatness. Mufasa did not ask for her affection, nor force her to treat him as her own. Instead, Eshe became a source of comfort for Mufasa; there was no â€˜stealingâ€™ involved. Obasi, on the other hand, initially disliked Mufasa as he wasnâ€™t a part of his bloodline or pride. Yet, this judgement shifts notably when Obasi displays genuine gratitude towards Mufasa for saving Esheâ€™s life during the white lion attack - something Mufasa did not have to do as after all he could have chosen to flee like Taka did. This clearly shows there was no â€˜theftâ€™ of Obasiâ€™s loyalty from Taka, it was earned.

2. Regarding Sarabi, she had her eyes on Mufasa from the start - not Taka. Amongst great speculation that Sarabi has purposefully â€˜led Taka onâ€™, this idea is torn apart when it is confirmed that she had in fact dismissed feelings for Mufasa initially although being royalty herself like Taka. Mufasa had also dismissed his original feelings for Sarabi upon their first encounter as he was aware that Taka liked her, hinted at in Mufasa and Sarabiâ€™s song â€˜Tell me itâ€™s youâ€™ ;the lyrics being â€˜I push you away, but the feelings come back just twice as strong.â€™ In the end, despite Mufasaâ€™s attempts to aid Taka in winning Sarabi over while rejecting his own feelings, it was Mufasa who won her heart - especially after she gains the knowledge that it was him who saved her during the elephant stampede, and was also him who had recognised the scent of the flowers from on her fur from the valley using his skills taught by Eshe. Yes, it is implied that Taka â€˜lovedâ€™ Sarabi, but destiny had already determined that Mufasa and Sarabi were meant to be together. There was never a relationship between Sarabi and Taka, as even Rafiki alluded to when describing Takaâ€™s emotional struggles.

3. Finally, the throne and Milele. Previous to Mufasa, there were no kings who had ruled this land, nor were there any lions. They were orphan due to Mufasaâ€™s purity and bravery. He became the first king of Milele and ultimately the greatest Lion King. It is never implied that Takaâ€™s destiny was to be king of Milele, simply that he were to be king of some pride at the eventual time.

author: @jordan1650
text: One of this movie's biggest mistakes was making Mufasa be adopted into the royal lion family, instead of both Mufasa and Scar being birth siblings because that honestly makes Scar's hatred and jealousy towards Mufasa look justified, which is completely backwards. Scar's hatred towards Mufasa is supposed to be unjustified and not to be sympathized with, but instead they just had Mufasa and the other characters unfairly take Scar's kingly position from him, which makes Scar look like the victim. Mufasa's kingly position in the 1994 movie was justified, while this movie made his position look corrupted. Or... if Disney really insists on changing Mufasa's and Scar's backstory around by having one of the brothers be adopted into the royal lion family to explain why their appearances are very different, then it should've been Scar. That would be at least be fitting for Scar's villainous character, since Scar would start off being very grateful and loving towards his brother Mufasa after getting adopted, but overtime he starts to get jealous over how much everyone respects Mufasa more than him, how Sarabi is attracted to Mufasa more than him, how Mufasa is often stronger and better than him in different ways, and that Mufasa is going to be the future king when Scar would rather be the king. Then that would all at least work for Scar's future villainous character.

author: @amarvelousstory1829
text:
Spoiler alert:
Sarabi was maybe the main reason of Scar's resentment towards Mufasa. Tika later known as Scar in the prequel was deeply hurt. He was really into Sarabi but she chose Mufasa yet Scar had has his chance with her but didn't know how to handle his feelings and everything that was happening. He tried to be courageous by saving his adoptive brother when there was the flood but didn't feel enough though. On top of that Mufasa was the one who saved Sarabi from a dangerous wound and he gave credential to Scar instead . Then Mufasa and Sarabi flirted ,Scar wasn't deprived of courage but it was an internal conflict between who he was and his close relationship with Mufasa (who is older) and who always took high responsibilities . He felt robbed when Sarabi chose him because everything Mufasa had he wanted too and could have if less into himself . So for me it was a love-hate Brotherhood story.

author: @sultanmahmudrabbi4859
text:
It is Scar / Taka who is the real hero in this film.

He saved Mufasa countless times but Mufasa couldn't sacrifice the throne to his brother.

Scar got his scar saving Mufasa from the villain Kiros, the white lion, he also saved Mufasa from drowning at last.

Guys, Scar is not the villain. He is the superhero in this film. He lost everything for Mufasa but Mufasa didn't pay him back. Thats why Scar became villain in The Lion King (2019).

Circumstances made Scar villian otherwise he was such a nice heroic lion.

author: @SHARIAN5
text:
Mufasa was the firstborn son of Ahadi and Uru, and the eldest brother of Prince Taka. During his childhood, Ahadi would often sit with Mufasa during the night, and told him the stories about the stars. Upon approaching adulthood, Mufasa would be declared king by his father, leaving Taka jealous. Taka made friends with Shenzi, Banzai, and Ed, hyenas who lived in the elephant graveyard and resented Ahadi. The hyenas plotted with Taka to find a means of humiliating Mufasa to devalue his credibility as future king. To accomplish this, Taka staged a buffalo attack, but the plan backfired and the raging buffalo instead injured Taka, giving him his infamous scar. A little while later, a red-billed hornbill named Zazu was almost getting cooked alive by the hyenas until Mufasa frightens them off making Zazu thankful and hopes he can be of service to the future king, which he doubts, Zazu eventually follows him around making the future king tired, Zazu disturbs his hunt and his primate time with his future mate Sarabi. One day, Zazu notices some vultures hovering and he asks Mufasa if he wants to fly over and see what's happening, but he is not concerned and decides to nap instead, but he later tells Mufasa that Sarabi is stuck in a pit and can't get out, but Zazu finds a tree trunk, which ultimately saves Sarabi, and Mufasa realizes that Zazu is useful around and he points him as a royal advisor, after his father's death he becomes the new king of Pride Rock, shortly thereafter he had a son named Simba which causes Scar to become even more jealous knowing that his nephew will inherit the throne someday and he couldnâ€™t.

author: @SimonaOmina
text:
Yâ€™all need to understand that this movie is a prequel to The Lion King from 2019, not the original story. In the original Lion King, Scar and Mufasa are brothers by blood .
The producer of The Lion King said it himself that they are related, not to mention the story was inspired by Hamlet, which is about biological brothers.
Besides that, in the original story, they call each other brothers. If they werenâ€™t blood-related, It would have likely been brought up at some point.

author: @juancruz-jg5pq
text:
Mufasa: The Lion King review: 'Pointless' and a 'contrived cash-in'.

This prequel to a re-make "never picks up momentum" â€“ "Don't the talented artists involved have anything better to do with their time?"

When the CEO of Disney announced in February that the studio would start relying more on "sequels and franchises", he wasn't joking. Already this year, we've hadÂ Inside Out 2Â andÂ Moana 2, and now we have Mufasa: The Lion King, a prequel toÂ 2019's photorealistic remakeÂ of 1994's much-loved cartoon.

Yes, we're talking about a prequel to a remake. And, yes, it's as pointless as that description makes it sound. This contrived cash-in may be worth sitting through on Disney+ if you're a Lion King superfan, but, like so many prequels, it devotes tremendous amounts of thought and energy to answering questions that nobody was asking in the first place. When did Simba's dad Mufasa meet his wife Sarabi? Where did Rafiki the mandrill get his walking stick? How did Zazu the hornbill become Mufasa's right-hand man (or, I suppose, right-paw bird)? The film is directed by Barry Jenkins, who made the Oscar-winningÂ Moonlight, and the songs are by Lin-Manuel Miranda, the most feted Hollywood and Broadway songwriter of his generation, so a more pressing question might be: don't the supremely talented artists involved have anything better to do with their time?
The big question the film answers, however, is how a lowly lion named Mufasa (Aaron Pierre) found his way to the idyllic Pride Lands with a friend who would become known as Scar (Kelvin Harrison Jr) â€“ and I can guarantee that nobody had been asking that question, because it contradicts everything that was established in The Lion King. If you remember, the whole point of the original film was that Mufasa's son Simba was the latest in a long line of monarchs who had protected the Pride Lands for generations, and that Mufasa's younger brother Scar was annoyed about his place in the pecking order. But presumably somebody at Disney became uncomfortable with that feudal premise, so they've scrapped it in favour of a more complicated and egalitarian origin story. The trouble is that this democratic new version fits the lore so badly that the producers might as well have renamed their film Mufasa: The Lion Prime Minister. It's as bad as PadmÃ© being "elected" as the queen of her planet when she was a 14-year-old girl in Star Wars: Episode I â€“ The Phantom Menace.

Anyway, the film opens with the news that Simba (Donald Glover) and his wife Nala (BeyoncÃ©) are about to have another cub, so they disappear into a forest without telling their daughter Kiara (Blue Ivy Carter) where they're going or why. (The motivation behind this bizarrely bad bit of parenting is never explained.) Kiara's babysitters are Timon the meerkat (Billy Eichner) and Pumbaa the warthog (Seth Rogen), and together they sit in a cave while Rafiki (John Kani) tells her about her grandfather Mufasa. After this unnecessarily long and complicated set-up, the main plot gets underway.Â (Spoiler ahead)

The film is all about lions talking to other lions while being pursued by yet more lions, so it can be visually monotonous â€“ it can also be challenging to keep track of which lion is which

author: @BudJr
text:
The first one only made a billion bucks because of nostalgia, and because they got the biggest stars on the planet to voice the characters. So they didnâ€™t need to give the animals facial expressions to add real emotion to the film. They didnâ€™t have to give any respect to â€œBe Preparedâ€, one of the greatest villain songs of all time. They had no problem with the characters singing â€œCan You Feel The Love Tonightâ€ during the DAY. They had no problem with making Scar so obviously mentally disturbed that he wouldnâ€™t be able fool anybody into doing anything.

â€œYes, the past can hurt. But you can either learn from it, or run from it.â€ In the original version, Rafiki told this to Simba. It was one of the most important lessons in the film, and they completely skipped over it because baboons donâ€™t hold sticks in real life. But for some reason Rafiki was allowed to have his stick in the fight scene at the end.

The hill Mufasa was on wasnâ€™t even close to being steep enough for him to fall off of it, but for some reason he acted like he couldnâ€™t climb it. In the remake, Mufasas death was his fault. Thereâ€™s no reason that he shouldnâ€™t have been able to climb that hill. And Mufasa shouldâ€™ve realized that in this version, Scar was clearly evil. Scar didnâ€™t try at any point in the new version to act innocent. If Mufasa realized it, he wouldâ€™ve never ended up in this situation in the first place.

This new movie doesnâ€™t have nostalgia to lean on as a crutch. Theyâ€™re telling a new story. They will have to put in some actual effort. The characters will have to actually emote. The villain will have to be more sophisticated, not just pure evil. If they want this movie to perform as well as the first one, they have to make a whole lot of changes. This trailer looks exactly the same as the first one. So Iâ€™m predicting this movie isnâ€™t going to perform well at all.

text:
I remember, when the first trailer came out.

And after years and years. We finally, get a Disney movie about Mufusa and Scar(Taka) becoming brothers and being brothers together.

author: @nilturiengreenleaf32610
text: Im 40. I love The Lion King very much.. but... i dont think i will watch this..i don't think i can. Mufasa's death truly broke my heart when i watched this as a young girl. Every time I hear the Lion King song, my heart squeezes and my eyes water due to the memory of the pain of his death. It has been such a very long time since I saw it but the memory is still clear as day. Watching this trailer feels like "seeing" those memories in front of me. ğŸ˜­ I did not even introduce my daughter (who is now 14) to the Lion King (and the Land before Time - another tear- and heartbreaker for a young girl!)     I just cant! ğŸ˜­ She learned about then through other people though.

author: @HalonElsa-MusicandStories
text:
Mufasa: The Lion King is an upcoming prequel to *The Lion King*, set to release on December 20, 2024. Directed by Barry Jenkins, the film will delve into the backstory of Mufasa, the iconic lion king. The movie will explore his rise to power, his relationship with his brother Taka (who later becomes the villain Scar), and how he became the beloved leader of the Pride Lands.

The story will be told through flashbacks, with Rafiki narrating the legend to Kiara, Simba and Nalaâ€™s daughter. This film will blend live-action and photoreal CGI, similar to the 2019 *The Lion King*. The cast includes Aaron Pierre as Mufasa, Kelvin Harrison Jr. as Scar, and Tiffany Boone as Sarabi, among others. Also, music will be provided by Lin-Manuel Miranda, known for his work on *Hamilton*.

Make sure to mark your calendar for its theatrical release in December 2024!

author: @DjBeefey
text: I do understand how the possibility of Mufasa being adopted is an acceptable story line for some and is fitting to some extent, However I feel this does change the storyline a bit from my perspective from the original Lion King movie when Scar delivers two statements in the beginning of the movie - "(1) If it isn't my "older" brother coming down to mix with the commoners. (2) When it comes to brute strength I'm afraid I'm on the shallow end of the "Gene" pool. Additionally Zazu mentions after that - "There's always one in the family sire! Two in my case actually". I do understand that I may be overthinking but under normal conversational circumstances "Gene" and "Older brother" were a bit more familial kind of words used? He could have just mentioned it as "Beloved brother / I'm not the stronger one" if the adopted line was going to be taken. Don't know

author: @Filius_Solis_777
text: According to the millennia-old tradition of the divine right of kings, a legitimate ruler who acts in accordance with the will of God through virtue and true justice bestows the gifts of prosperity and peace upon society. Under his righteous government, stability and economic well-being flourish, and social order is assured. However, when the throne is occupied by an usurper, a tyrant, or a ruler without legitimacy, the fabric of civilization disintegrates, giving way to chaos, decline, and the scourges of crises, crime, famine, plagues, and wars. The morality and legitimacy of the ruler are the pillars of stability; their absence plunges society into the abyss of disorder. This tradition imposes a double burden on the monarch: his responsibility is not only toward men but also toward God. He must govern with wisdom and fairness, for divine displeasure can be as relentless as that of the people. The fate of a nation is therefore closely tied to the character of its ruler. A kingâ€™s inability to maintain the favor and trust of his subjects makes his reign unsustainable, dragging him into an inexorable cycle of crises and suffering. To preserve his legitimacy, it is imperative that the ruler aligns his actions with the sublime values expected by both the deity and the community. This tradition does not merely justify royal authority but elevates royal power to an ethical dimension, where the nationâ€™s prosperity depends on the virtuous behavior of the ruler. Social harmony thus arises from this intimate relationship between ruler and subjects, in which royal justice and morality are regarded as indispensable foundations for collective well-being.

author: @nathanielheitzer5183
text:
Kiros: "The circle is broken. There will be one lion king."
Me: (to Kiros) "Yeah, that lion king won't be you, snowflake!"
Kiro: (exchanges his look at me at 1:39) "Who are you that would stand against me, human?"
Me: "I may be just a human, but I'm willing to help fix the circle, and follow the rightful king."
Kiros: "Is that so?
Me: "Yeah! As a matter of fact, it most certainly and definitely is."
Kiros: "Well, what are you going to do about it when I am the king giving orders? Hmmmmm?
Me: "I've never served royalty before, but if was to, I'd only serve the true king, and I won't serve a false king."
Kiros: Then, serve... (bares his claws) A DEAD ONE!"
Me: "BACK OFF!
Kiros: "And... what are you going to do about it?
Me: "I abject! You'll have to go through me to get kill the king as well as Queen Eshe, Mufasa and Taka and take the throne, you gotta go through me!"
Kiros: (Laughs menacingly) "You aren't serious, are you fool? This is nothing but proof that they are all cowards!" (Continues to laugh menacingly, along with his pride.)
Me: (Gives Kiros an "I'm serious" look that tells him that I'm not joking.)

author: @ShadowOnTheWall666
text:
I am disappointed that this is in the live CGI universe and not the OG and uses the birth name for Scar in the non-canon Six New Adventures, Taka meaning 'waste' or 'trash' which fits better in that universe where he was the rejected second son. Considering how this concept clashes with The Lion Guard, I am going to assume the live CGI universe is an alternate TLK.
Furthermore, I agree with what others have said about the voices, those voices just don't fit the characters.

The first live CGI seemed to focus its cast on African voice actors, no doubt for authenticity as was done with Harry Potter with the exception of Timon and Pumbaa, hence James Earl Jones being the only OG asked to return. (R.I.P. I honestly wondered if that dude might live forever). What happened to that?

Granted as an OG fan since its 1994 release, I never could fully accept a Scar without Jeremey Irons' voice so perhaps I am being a bit biased.

I do, however, appreciate the concept that Scar was the rightful heir and lost it to a brother who wasn't even blood related to him. It gives him more depth and ties more appropriately into the line "when at last I am given my dues" in Scar's villain song 'Be Prepared'.

author: @Cuban20
text:
Scar's name Taka is Swahili for Trash. It comes from the first back story (A Tale of Two Lions). He was the younger brother and his family hated him. Saw him as useless. Which is what led to him becoming evil.


Plus Mufasa was a spoiled brat. In the Lion Guard the story was more interesting. His name was Askari (Soldier) and since he would never see the throne, his parents had him trained to be a military leader instead. He even gained the roar of the Elders. The reason he became scar is because he stopped an evil Lion and his Serpent side kick from overthrowing the royal family.

The serpent gave him that scar and the venom that flowed through his veins was magical. It made him evil. If his family had tried to cure him he would probably never have become evil. But even Mufasa brushed it off. In fact he was the one who named him Scar to mock him.


And the rest of the Lion Guard started to call him that too. Which led to him killing them all with the Roar of the Elders. And lost his power when he did that. And ended up being partially banished into the Hyena's territory.

author: @qriusjorj38
text: Hi Disney. I can guarantee that putting short content, like trailers and updates for released content akin to the one for Deadpool & Wolverine, behind an adwall to already paying Disney+ subscribers will have way more detrimental effects to your pocketbooks in the long term than your advisors are telling you. They're only looking in their own short term interests and banking on the relatively miniscule returns based solely on this tiny boost to ad revenue. Your loss in brand confidence, subscriber base, and long term losses in revenue at your theme parks will far outweigh any short term benefits from this ad revenue. We have already swallowed the bitter pill of ads in movies and shows that we've already paid for; adding very short term content to this will alienate many more patrons than you think. You may look at it as ad revenue per minute of content but we see it as advertisement time per minute of (already paid for) content, and the numbers are really grim. Unless you're already looking to cut and run, this is a terrible look.

author: @jeremylevant
text: As I pay attention to this trailer, I see why mufasa was put in place to be King....Scar is a coward...slick and savvy...he was mischievous....he set Simba up in the original movie and even Mufasa....looking at this trailer, Scar was a coward and not fit for a King....watch it and see how Mufasa was ready to fight the White Lions and Scar knocked them both off the waterfall, basically RUNNING from conflict and saying he saved them...he (Mufasa) even said I came back to "protect" you brother.... remember when the Hyenas has Simba and Nala cornered? Who jumped in to save them? Mufasa!... remember when Simba challenged Scar to battle, he cheated and gained the upperhand by throwing fire and ash in his face... even blamed the Hyenas when Simba ran down on him and said they were the real enemy....a real KING stands up and accepts ANY challenge in the pride.... that's just my theory on this storyline cuz I couldn't figure out if Scar was the rightful King, why'd he get overlooked and watching this and going back to the movie....I can see why....

author: @DanielDamasco-z6q
text:
The white lion massacre the family of mufasa to take the pride rock (mufasa kingdom). While mufasa was escape. Taka(scar) found mufasa in floating log (scar kingdom) became friends and brothers. Everytime mufasa smell the familiar scent(the pride rock) when mufasa and taka became a young man. ( Not fully grown lion) The two went on hunting like kiara did (simba daughter) but mufasa wanted follow the voices on his head and the familiar smell to go back to the kingdom where he belong . Taka(scar) accompanied him because they are brothers. Upon adventure the two meets ZAZU,RAFIKI,SARABI. Mufasa and taka challenge the white lion and win the battle. The brothers take back the kingdom of pride rock and mufasa became a king. The two was live happy UNTIL. Taka(scar) was next in line to became a king after mufasa but the hairball was born (SIMBA) . Taka became MAD and jealous that's why he tried to kill his nephew. The rest is on the lion king 1( 1995)

Simplest summary. Thank you!

author: @n0ta_cat797
text: Im gonna be completely honest in my opinion. For me at least, this trailer looks a lot better then the first one. It more paints an idea of the story they want to tell. It does make a few slight changes from tje original origin story so it seems there telling it in a slightly different way. This story has also never been told in a movie like this. Im still not entirely convinced on the cgi i wish they went with a style somewhat like 2d animated characters in a live action world or just made them look more like cartoon characters. I know a lot of people are saying that this movie is gonna get destroyed in the box office by sonic but im not entirely convinced. Despite all the criticism that the 2019 live action adaptation got it still mad over $1 Billion in the global box office. I feel like this movie will still do well with younger demographics especially since in European territories sonic doesn't release until December 26th. Also i feel like sonic has always more been targeted towards teenagers and most smaller kids wouldn't be interested in seeing it. Despite this i still think both movies will do well in the box office

author: @kittytetra1040
text:
I see many upset that Taka was a prince and Mufasa wasn't, but this is my idea on what this movie might be doing:

1)Mufasa mentioned he's lost, meaning he's not a stray(orphan) and was from a different pride, most likely in my opinion pride rock (but got separated from his pride somehow). Mufasa must have gotten separated at a young age or hit his head, so he has little to no memory of where he came from. If anything, he's always been the rightful prince of pride rock.

2)Taka/Scar's pride doesn't look like they are even in pride rock, so that makes Taka a prince to a different pride.

So, I think as the two journey as young adults, Mufasa learns of his origin, and travels to pride Rock, where he's given back his title as King of Pride Rock. Meanwhile, Taka, who was a prince of a different Pride, lost his pride to the white Lion and slowly loses everything. So, while Mufasa keeps gaining, Taka is slowly losing, becoming more envious and Jealous of the Lion he saved. Thus, why he feels he deserves the place as king, for if it wasn't for him, Mufasa wouldn't even be alive (Ironic I know). Then the two fight, Mufasa give scar the scar, and thus bringing us to where the other "live action" takes place.

Now maybe Mufasa also steals the lioness scar had a crush on, Sarabi, which doesn't help. But that's my idea of what may happen. Could be wrong, but only time will tell once the movie comes out. :)

author: @daltonsturgeon4024
text: I'm honestly very excited for this movie. This is most likely a very unpopular opinion, but I actually loved the 2019 remake of 'The Lion King'. I'd even go as far as to say it's better than the original; though the original will always hold a very special place in my heart as my favorite movie. This is only the first trailer, but so far it looks promising; the animation especially looks excellent. I'm staying cautiously optimistic, obviously, but I'm very curious to see where this goes and can't wait to see it. I just pray this movie does good, that's all I want. That and more Lion King movies, namely a remake of 'The Lion King 2'. Most likely not gonna happen, but guy can dream.

text: Okay so guys hear me out, listening to  "be prepared"again I might kind of have hinted at this story, because scar constantly makes reference to being given his due, and he talks about murdering mufasa and taking the throne as "an injustice deliciously squared"I mean it might be a bit of a stretch but these lines don't seem to me like a second son who simply thinks that he should have been the king even though he knows that's not how it works, I mean it could be that he thinks the Injustice is that he wasn't born first, but I honestly think this makes more sense if he was the one meant to have the throne and then he feels cheated out of it, I'm still probably not going to watch this movie, but there might have been seeds for something like this, even when the first Lion King was written, I know that, best version of events might just be the writers interpretation of what the song meant but at least it might have a bit more basis in reality than just making something up

author: @henriettaabeyta1457
text: Careful Disney you've created a motion picture that saddened some of your fans quite quick with this trailer. And you've made these lions look rougher than the real ones letting them seem like restless wrestlers, Scar's now worse than Steele in Balto's first film. And Mufasa's not what he used to be in this type of movie, he doesn't look calm and tolerant, he looks playful. Orphan scenes is like throwing away the family tree secrets online and in  a few of the picture books these brothers already have. It's the bat eared fox I wish you didn't subtract from the animated film myself. I don't like how rough the Lion Guard treats the circle of life either, Simba treats others as if he doesn't care about balance of life, but cares too much about safety.
